Let me first say that if you look historically, ING has always had a very large equity book and benefited from that book over the years quite strongly. At the same time, in the recent years, we have been – and in that equity book there is basically two portions; one was basically the equity portion of the asset and liability management book of the various insurance companies. And second, a surplus which we called the strategic book. I think that but, in the past those two were basically comingled in one big book.

I think what's -- what we have done most recently is basically differentiate between the ALM book which basically has been put down to the various insurance companies and kept the strategic book at the group level. Now at the same time, in both the ALM books of their various insurance companies and in the strategic book, first of all we've reduced structurally the overall amount in the past compared to a few years ago. And second, I think that we've managed this more actively in terms of – basically work through the cyclically of the equity market by writing protection on our books both in the ALM books and the strategy books.

So, I think at this point of time, we see that we are pretty well protected and I think the question is – and the real question for me is let's keep protected until we need to but at some time we need also to reopen the positions to basically continue to get the benefits within the ALM book and to some extent although, less extended than in the past in the strategic book. So, I think that's where we are today, but we have to manage this pretty dynamically, which we do since a couple of years.
So, what would you say is the strategic part of the 11 billion that you've got the moment? Can you put a number on that?
I think, yes, Koos.

What you have is you have in the insurance company in the Netherlands for instance where we have the portfolio close to 5 billion. So that is the part, which fits that ALM profile. At the banking side, we have, I think it is in total 2.5 billion and that is the stakes, which we have in the company. So you can consider them strategic, but from a different prospective, we see these as strategic holdings, but not so much in ALM profile foreign insurance company. And so, those two, I would rate typically strategic. On the other part, if you look at wide definition of the credit -- of the equity side, we have strategically said that in the US portfolio, we like to see some increases in the private equity and in the alternative space and that is also a strategic element and Tom, I think it is in total or...
About 3%.
About 3%.
But over time we're trying to go to 5%.
Yeah.
For the US portfolios.
Yeah.
Okay.
So, the...
Okay.
Thank you very much, for your answers.
Thanks.
Thank you. Our final question comes from Carlo Ponfoort, of AEK. Please go ahead.
Good morning, Carlo Ponfoort from AEK. Three questions.

My first question is on Retail Banking. In the press release you mentioned strong competition of savings puts a lot of pressure on interest margins. I want to know if it's mainly the Netherlands and Belgium what you are talking about or is it also in Poland?
My second question is on the Alt-A book, if we are looking now we're already six weeks in the third quarter. Is there a trends that 18 billion Alt-A is further declining?

And finally, my third question is on ING Direct, I must say the US was performing quite well, but on the other hand I see in Germany, quite a negative trend that's now continuing in past five quarters. Profit is already down 34% compared to the year and you see no real assets growth and so my questions is more in Germany going forward, the rate at the moment you are providing is 3.25% and of course competition is severe in the German market? That's all my questions. Thank you.

Okay. So, first of all on the savings market. Let me say that the competition for savings is a bit everywhere in the world and not only in the Netherlands and Belgium, and that we see that in any country, including Poland. But at the same time, I think in Poland it benefits us, because we are one of – we have basically taken a pretty aggressive marketing stance in Poland, to basically grow our business. So, we are probably one of the major benefit – beneficiary of this.

In the Netherlands and Belgium, I think, we have introduced new products in the first quarter, and the second quarter to basically attract our customers and to increase our volumes. And I'm happy to say that our volumes are increasing at a nice speed, particularly most recently. So, I think, that that's good.

I think that when turning to ING Direct, I think, first of all, I would like to say that we have always say that diversification of our business portfolio in ING Direct was a key ingredient of our strategy. And I think that history has proved us right in this, because we have seen in the past that the Europe had a very nice yield curve and basically was generating the profits when the US had a flat to negative yield curve and was little bit struggling. And now we see exactly the reverse, where the US has a very nice yield curve and is basically able to make a nice amount of money, nice profits when Europe is struggling a bit, because of the shape of the curve. So, no, of course, I think that in Europe despite this curve, there is a lot of competition for savings.

In Germany is also a country in which there is a lot of competition, but there also we are seen by most people as a very competitive and we are basically putting our pricing in a very competitive range. We are also introducing different pricing strategies to respond to a certain demand of customers. We are also introducing new products like the payment accounts and that basically attracts more customers.

So I think that -- I think we are always balancing here the overall profit of ING Direct as a whole, our competitiveness long-term in those markets, the attractiveness for customers and I think the diversification model works. So we should be happy and I hope that maybe that the yield curve will reopen slightly in Europe in the coming year and that should give us some additional breathing space. So I think that's basically where we are.

Maybe on the – it's Koos. On the Alt-A section there are further deteriorations. Let me answer that in three parts. One is if you look at values. So do we see further deteriorations? One of the things is, clearly, over the month of July there is witnessed a decline in values of Alt-A securities. Overall, you can say anything what is private label, at this moment is declining in value and that is the factor which I mentioned and that is the fact that indeed there is at the moment no natural holders of paper, because nobody can easily finance it. So liquidity plays a role.

But then one other factor that plays a role and that is credit as well. And if you look at credits, what I hinted to you in the presentation is underlying pool performance you do see a deterioration. Now part of it is expected because there is normal with the aging and it's also if you look at credit enhancement that is something what you can absorb.

But that brings to the third part and that is more the outlook. I think what we just received from S&P is refreshed outlook, so based on current pool deteriorations you see raters creating new scenarios, which basically have doubled the amount of expected losses ultimately in the portfolio. So in that sense, you try to run your portfolio against the most fresh scenarios, which you have seen and that is where you live with and that is where you base your calculations on. So I think an element of future deterioration is what is embedded in the scenarios, which I see right now with S&P.
Thank you.
Excuse me, sir. There are no further questions at this time. Please continue with any last points you wish to raise.

Well, thank you very much. Well, I would like to thank you for joining us this morning and of course, there will be other occasions in the next few days to answer questions. And now we are going to the press conference. Thank you for joining us and see you soon. Bye-bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the ING Groep second quarter 2008 results conference call. Thanks for participating. You may now disconnect.
